messageBody:
Hi,

That is a very good point.
Rote learning would work up until you encounter a word which wasn't (or was spelled differently) in your dictionary.

I've heard that sign languages are pretty independent of written/spoken languages anyway, so a change of alphabet wouldn't affect them.
It seems to me (and this is only my opinion since I really have no right to say one way or the other) that someone who's everyday language was a sign language would prefer a system like SignWriting for their written materials anyway.

Braille has a near direct mapping with roman letters so a new system would be needed, any thoughts?

btw - Sorry for being 'dead' for so long, I've been having ISP issues.

tim_rice09 wrote:

There is one area where standard spellings with any reform perposal
are needed, sign language. For the hearing impared any writing system
is ideographic since sound-spelling is impossible. Also, for a new
sign language new hand signs are needed. A braille like system is
needed as well.
